content.html:
On The Side has been abuzz this week with blogs about music, CDs and DVDs. Sam, Trev, Sam and Mike have all chimed in with their personal opinions, dividing the community on how physical media is appreciated in a digital culture. Here are my thoughts‚Ä¶

Rewind

As a millennial (just about), I grew up with vinyl, cassettes and CDs to consume music (let‚Äôs not talk radio or TV ‚Äì that‚Äôs a whole other debate). My parents collected their own music libraries across all formats; dad with his rock and electronic music, mum with her pop, disco and soul.

I have fond memories of my dad‚Äôs first portable Kenwood CD player sent from his brother in Japan along with Eurythmics, Fine Young Cannibals and Status Quo as a starting collection. It plugged into his Kenwood stack hifi he meticulously looked after, along with the delightfully clear speaker system he‚Äôd spent months shopping around for and fine-tuning (‚Äùdon‚Äôt touch that equaliser, Simon!‚Äù)

The weekends were the time we‚Äôd all listen along to one of their albums from the collection; mum screaming along to Whitney tunes, dad head-bopping along to the bass lines of his deeper selection. We‚Äôd also spend many road trips heading up and down the M1 to Derby playing cassettes on loop. Carribean Queen is a distinct memory in Mum‚Äôs car along with Bomb The Bass in dad‚Äôs.

We‚Äôd sing or hum along knowing the words after learning them from the album liners, playing them relentlessly, almost rote learning every lyric written in sequential order.

These were the days of well crafted albums, when you KNEW what was coming next from the artist‚Äôs (or producers‚Äô) compilation.

Music was treated as the craft it deserves by the listeners.

Crate-Digging

As I grew older and started earning an income, this love and passion for music continued when I‚Äôd spend most my money in HMV and Virgin Megastore. Many a weekend would be spent in Northampton shopping centre, flipping through aisles of CDs and vinyl, selecting the most valuable choice with my limited funds. (These were the days when singles would range from 99p to ¬£3.99 on CD, some limited edition vinyl could cost over ¬£10).

I grew my collection over years of browsing the stores, often spending hours alone hogging one of the record players, trying to find THAT track that captured me to be repeated endlessly on loop.

This hobby continued as I went to university, often spending my menial student loan (and overdraft) on records over decent food ‚Äì beans on toast was substantial enough to allow for another record. I used to jump in the car with my (employed) DJ friends, head up to Leeds or other nearby cities to pull apart HMV‚Äôs biggest record collections for that one-in-a-thousand tune to play at our next gig.

I‚Äôm hopefully painting a romantic picture here, a true love for music that was tangible, unique, a real craft of art.

Then MP3s came along.

Digital Love

Now don‚Äôt get me wrong. The digital revolution was a game-changer in many ways. With the internet came access to content that was typically inaccessible to most (thanks Tim). Obviously piracy was a serious issue, really challenging the music industry to adapt quickly and maintain control/income of their productions for their artist‚Äôs royalties. Mass produced music was feeling the pain when MP3s were gaining popularity, with early MP3 players quickly filling up with multiple albums.

Back in our university dorms, we‚Äôd use Napster or Kazaa quickly downloading the biggest hits for our parties, burning collections to CD for others to enjoy later. It was terrible looking back but with little-to-no income and students need to ‚Äúlive life to the full‚Äù, it became common practice for many to abuse this new-found access to music.

But whilst the masses enjoyed popular music, I was also spending many evenings browsing specialist directories and forums for my favourite genre: house music. This was an opportunity for aspiring DJs and producers to share their creations with dedicated fans, getting immediate feedback without the high cost and commitment of record presses or label distribution contracts.

Digital music enabled artists with rapid distribution & faster feedback whilst listeners had immediate easy access to endless choices across the globe.

As I graduated from university and found a job, online stores were starting to provide more platforms for DJs to browse new music and reward artists with a suitable income. Granted, most tracks ranged from 79p to ¬£2.99, pennies compared to the physical media equivalent, but I assumed this was due to reduced production and distribution costs ‚Äì royalties were the same.

During this time, I was now producing my own DJ mixes for podcast distribution, generally featuring the latest house and dance tracks to promote them to masses. At it‚Äôs peak, I got regular thanks and feedback from artists, producers and labels for growing their listener base and giving them the recognition they often deserved.

Because of the volume of music featured and regular frequency, I‚Äôd spend hours every week scouring the specialist online stores for the right 15 tracks ‚Äì reminiscent of those crate-digging days of the 90s but, instead, scrolling through webpages of music to handpick a larger selection.

But I still felt like I ‚Äúowned‚Äù that download, even if it wasn‚Äôt a tangible product I could hold.

I‚Äôd often burn a monthly selection to CD for listening in the car, especially when I‚Äôd typically spend a few hours every day driving to and from work with a reasonable-quality hifi system for appreciation the full audio range of heavy bass-lines and beats. This gave me something more tangible to own, and I‚Äôd familiarise with the curation of that playlist, typically taking the listener on an acoustic journey through the many sub-genres I personally selected.

Fast Forward

Let‚Äôs come back to modern day. I‚Äôve continued to purchase musical downloads from the likes of Traxsource, Beatport, Bandcamp and occasionally Apple. I still prefer to possess a copy of the music I enjoy, and reward artists with the (minuscule) royalties they collect from distributors and labels.

However, over the past few years, I‚Äôve rekindled my love for physical media and vinyl. As the pandemic hit, I decided to get my old decks out the loft (inspired by all the superstar DJ‚Äôs broadcasting from their homes) and flip through my old vinyl stored in the loft. I did consider all the boxes full of CD‚Äôs as well but decided to leave them for another rainy day.

Since getting the bug, I then took to eBay, Discogs and local charity shops to build up my collection again. This has resulted in another side project known as The Archive Collection where I post my records (mostly 12‚Äù and 7‚Äù vinyl) to an Instagram account. Initially, this was for my own benefit as a way to catalogue my collection in a convenient way but it also provides an opportunity to engage with fellow vinyl fans or even the featured artists. Where possible, I namecheck artists, producers or labels who are on Instagram and they regularly get a reaction which brings another joy to me ‚Äì connecting with the original artists and community who share the love for similar music tastes.

Eject

When this conversation started in our community, I had plenty thoughts and opinions on music in digital or physical form. I‚Äôm not sure how to conclude but I‚Äôve enjoyed reminiscing over my musical journey so far, reflecting on feelings and motions and sharing for anyone else to compare.

I guess my overall opinion is both formats have their place; digital music is convenient for instant access of infinite content but physical music provides the full story, a romantic link back to the origins of the art form and a respectable hat-tip back to the artist‚Äôs intentions.

They can both live in harmony in a modern world.

children.name: is `file_get_contents(‚Äúphp://input‚Äù)` the only way to get post data from `fetch` and is it safe to use async- and hack-wise?

content.html:
I‚Äôm trying to rewrite my JQuery $.post() code via native fetch() function. And it seems like the only way to do it with PHP server code is using file_get_contents("php://input"). I do it like it is shown here and here:

js code:

fetch('/myscript.php', {
    method: 'post',
    mode: "same-origin",
    credentials: "same-origin",
    body: JSON.stringify({par1:par1, par2:par2})
}).then(response => response.text())
.then(output => {
  // do stuff
});

myscript.php:

$input = json_decode(file_get_contents('php://input'), true);
// do stuff with $input['par1'], $input['par2']
echo $output;

There are two things which makes me worried:

  1. The project has more than one fetch call like this. What if two fetch functions are called simultaneously with two different php script files? They both will access php://input at the same time. Won‚Äôt it lead to a conflict?

  2. With $.post() I was able to check if myscript.php hasn‚Äôt been called directly by a hacker with this line of code:

    if ($_SERVER['HTTP_X_REQUESTED_WITH'] != 'XMLHttpRequest') die('Hack attempt!');

    but with the new approach $_SERVER['HTTP_X_REQUESTED_WITH'] is undefined for some reason. Is there a way to ensure myscript.php is called with fetch or php://input ensures it automatically?

  3. fetch is pretty modern function, but json_decode(file_get_contents('php://input'), true) looks pretty weird and intended for some other use case. Isn‚Äôt there a better way to fetch data from a php-based server?

Answer

  1. No. Each script invocation has its own php://input.
  2. How does that check if it‚Äôs called by a hacker? Nothing stops a hacker from sending that header. But if you really want it, you can add the header yourself (which is what a hacker would do):
fetch('/myscript.php', {
    method: 'post',
    mode: "same-origin",
    headers: {"X-Requested-With": "XMLHttpRequest"},
    credentials: "same-origin",
    body: JSON.stringify({par1:par1, par2:par2})
}).then(response => response.text())
.then(output => {
  // do stuff
});
  1. You can send url-encoded parameters instead of JSON. Then PHP will parse them into $_POST as with normal forms.
fetch('/myscript.php', {
    method: 'post',
    mode: "same-origin",
    headers: {
        "X-Requested-With": "XMLHttpRequest", 
        "Content-type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded"
    },
    credentials: "same-origin",
    body: `par1=${encodeURIComponent(par1)}&par2=${encodeURIComponent(par2)}`
}).then(response => response.text())
.then(output => {
  // do stuff
});

When logging in to your account, a safe way is to log in to the account on the same computer or mobile phone through the same browser. If you frequently sign in to your account on different devices through different browsers, your account activity may be considered suspicious and the service provider will disable your account.

content.html:
The Raspberry Pi is a series of credit card-sized single-board computers developed in the United Kingdom by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to promote the teaching of basic computer science in schools and developing countries. Official Link: Raspberry Pi Foundation Homepage, Raspberry Pi Computer Homepage

This list is a collection of tools, projects, images and resources conforming to the Awesome Manifesto

Contributions very welcome but first see Contributing

Contents

  • Models
  • OS Images
  • Tools
  • Projects
  • Resources

Models

The complete collection of (consumer) Raspberry Pi models consist of:

  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model A & Model B (2012, discontinued)
  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model B+ (July, 2014)
  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model A+ (November, 2014)
  • Raspberry Pi 2, Model B (February, 2015)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero (November, 2015)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model B (March, 2016)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W (February, 2017)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model B+ (March, 2018)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model A+ (November, 2018)
  • Raspberry Pi 4, Model B (June, 2019)
  • Raspberry Pi 400 (November, 2020)
  • Raspberry Pi Pico (January, 2021)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W (October, 2021)

OS Images

  • Alpine Linux ‚Äì Security-oriented, lightweight Linux distribution based on musl libc and busybox.
  • Android Things ‚Äì Build connected devices for a wide variety of consumer, retail, and industrial applications.
  • Arch Linux ARM ‚Äì Lightweight and flexible Linux distribution that tries to Keep It Simple.
  • balenaOS ‚Äì open source OS to run Docker containers on embedded devices that‚Äôs been designed for reliability and proven in production.
  • BerryBoot ‚Äì Bootloader/universal OS installer, with support to VNC and HDMI-CEC.
  • CentOS ‚Äì CentOS on the Raspberry Pi.
  • chilipie-kiosk ‚Äì Image which boots directly into full-screen Chrome, perfect for dashboards and build monitors.
  • Channels DVR Server ‚Äì Custom image for Channels DVR Server which provides a whole home DVR system.
  • DietPi ‚Äì Minimal image designed to fit on a 2GB SD card, with tons of configurable settings and scripts.
  • DroneBridge ‚Äì A WifiBroadcast extension to make for a real alternative to DJI Lightbridge and other similar systems.
  • EZ-WifiBroadcast ‚Äì Affordable Wireless Digital HD Video Transmission made easy.
  • FabScanPi ‚Äì FabScanPi is an open source 3D laser scanner using the Raspberry Pi Camera Module.
  • Fedora ‚Äì Linux Fedora distribution built for the Pi.
  • FreeBSD ‚Äì FreeBSD is an advanced computer operating system used to power modern servers, desktops, and embedded platforms.
  • Gentoo ‚Äì Gentoo Stage 3 tarball for Raspberry Pi.
  • Gladys Assistant ‚Äì Gladys, a privacy-first, open-source home assistant.
  • Hass.io ‚Äì Home automation operating system/application for embedded device, also available standalone.
  • HypriotOS ‚Äì Minimal Debian-based operating system, optimized to run Docker.
  • Kali Linux ‚Äì Penetration Testing & Ethical Hacking Linux distro for ARM devices.
  • Kano OS ‚Äì Open-source OS for exploration, creation, and play ‚Äì free for Raspberry Pi and the new Pi 3.
  • Lakka ‚Äì Retro-gaming on the Raspberry Pi built entirely on RetroArch.
  • LibreELEC ‚Äì Just enough OS for Kodi
  • Manjaro ‚Äì Friendly, open-source Linux distribution for Raspberry Pi.
  • Minibian ‚Äì Minimal Raspbian (lighter than Jessie Lite).
  • MoodleBox ‚Äì The MoodleBox provides a Moodle learning management system on Raspberry Pi.
  • motionEyeOS ‚Äì Linux distribution that turns a single-board computer into a video surveillance system.
  • NetBSD ‚Äì NetBSD is a free, fast, secure, and highly portable Unix-like Open Source operating system.
  • NextCloudPi ‚Äì Nextcloud ready image based on Raspbian. Features Nextcloud 11 running on Raspbian 8, with PHP 7 and HTTP2 enabled Apache server.
  • NOOBS ‚Äì New Out Of the Box Software, an easy OS installer for beginners.
  • OctoPi ‚Äì Distribution for 3d printers.
  • OpenELEC ‚Äì Open Embedded Linux Entertainment Center, a very lightweight Kodi build.
  • OpenHABian ‚Äì A preconfigured version of the OpenHAB home automation software.
  • OpenMediaVault ‚Äì OpenMediaVault is the next generation network attached storage (NAS) solution based on Debian Linux containing services like SSH, (S)FTP, SMB/CIFS, DAAP media server, RSync, BitTorrent client and many more.
  • openSUSE ‚Äì openSUSE is a major Linux distribution that has images based for its stable release Leap and rolling release Tumbleweed. Images can be found for many of the Pis, including the Raspberry Pi 3 and Raspberry Pi 4.
  • OpenWRT ‚Äì OpenWrt is described as a Linux distribution for embedded devices for network management.
  • OSMC ‚Äì Open Source Media Centre, based on Kodi.
  • PiDeck ‚Äì Small form factor DVS system allowing you to control digital music files with timecode vinyl.
  • PiNet ‚Äì System to manage Raspberry Pi classrooms.
  • PirateBox ‚Äì Anonymous offline mobile file-sharing and communications system.
  • RasComm RaspberryPi MorseCode Translator ‚Äì RasComm is a communication device that translates plain text into Morse code (IMC) visually or audibly.
  • Raspberry Pi OS ‚Äì The official supported Raspberry Pi OS (previously called ‚ÄúRaspbian‚Äù), based on Debian and available as a lite version.
  • Raspbian ‚Äì Raspbian is a free operating system based on Debian optimized for the Raspberry Pi hardware.
  • RasPlex ‚Äì Plex client for the Raspberry Pi.
  • Recalbox ‚Äì Drag & drop light-weight retro-gaming and media center on the Raspberry Pi.
  • RetroPie ‚Äì Retro-gaming on the Raspberry Pi.
  • Risc OS ‚Äì Non-Linux OS originated from the group that developed the ARM microprocessor.
  • Rocket Show ‚Äì Play synced backing tracks, videos and DMX light-sequences live on stage.
  • RuneAudio ‚Äì Free and open source OS that turns embedded hardware into Hi-Fi music players.
  • SamplerBox ‚Äì Drop‚Äôn‚Äôplay sampler: drop .WAV samples on the SD card, and play!
  • SARPi ‚Äì Stands for the Slackware ARM on Raspberry Pi.
  • Snappy Ubuntu Core ‚Äì Official (minimal) Ubuntu distribution for IoT.
  • Twister OS ‚Äì Skinned version of Raspberry Pi OS with preinstalled apps like box86 and Retropie to introduce noobs to Linux and Raspberry Pi.
  • Ubuntu MATE ‚Äì Ubuntu distribution for the Raspberry Pi based on MATE desktop.
  • Ubuntu Server ‚Äì Ubuntu Server distribution for the Raspberry Pi.
  • Volumio ‚Äì Headless audiophile music player, designed to play music with the highest possible fidelity.
  • Windows 10 ARM ‚Äì Community maintained Windows 10 on Raspberry Pi.
  • Windows 10 IoT Core ‚Äì Windows 10 distribution for IoT.

Tools

  • Alpha ‚Äì Remotely load, debug and test bare-metal programs using GDB with this system-level GDB server.
  • ApplePi Bakery ‚Äì macOS application to easily install/backup/restore images onto an SD card.
  • Atlas toolkit ‚Äì Very lightweight and easy to install toolkit to write in Python single-page web applications to pilot your RPi, without having to install a web server.
  • CusDeb ‚Äì Web UI for creating custom images with specific packages installed.
  • balenaEtcher ‚Äì SD card burner app that is simple for end users, extensible for developers, and works on any platform.
  • Drago ‚Äì Flexible configuration manager for Wireguard networks that is perfect for establishing secure overlays spanning multiple Raspberry Pis.
  • Hardened Kernel Builder for RPi ‚Äì Cross-compile the Linux kernel for Raspberry Pi with enhanced security using a single command.
  • HealthyPi ‚Äì HAT which includes vital health monitoring like ECG, respiration, pulse oximetry and optional blood pressure & body temperature sensing.
  • iotwifi ‚Äì Wifi AP + Client management in 8MB Docker Container, with REST API for controlling wifi client and station modes simultaneously.
  • OpenVPN-Setup ‚Äì Shell script to set up Raspberry Pi as an OpenVPN server.
  • Orangetool ‚Äì Control functions for Single-Board computers in Python.
  • pi-gen ‚Äì Tool used to create the raspberrypi.org Raspbian images. This can be used to create your own custom images with specific packages installed, etc.
  • PiBakery ‚Äì The blocks based, easy to use setup tool for Raspberry Pi.
  • Pieman ‚Äì Script for creating custom images based on Raspbian, Devuan, Ubuntu and Alpine Linux.
  • Pimod ‚Äì Reconfigure Raspberry Pi images with an easy, Docker-like configuration file.
  • PiShrink ‚Äì Bash script that automatically shrinks a pi image that will then resize to the max size of the SD card on boot.
  • PiVPN ‚Äì Create a full-featured OpenVPN/WireGuard VPN Server with a single bash command.
  • Pi-Apps ‚Äì The most popular app store for Raspberry Pi computers, 100% open-source bash scripts.
  • Processing ‚Äì Processing Development Environment running on Raspberry Pi.
  • Pwnagotchi ‚Äì Pwnagotchi is an AI based Wi-Fi cracking tool that learns from its surrounding WiFi environment to maximize the crackable WPA key material it captures.
  • RaspAP-webgui ‚Äì A simple, responsive web interface to control wifi, hostapd and related services on the Raspberry Pi.
  • Raspberry Pi Imager ‚Äì An easy way to install Raspberry Pi OS and other operating systems to an SD card ready to use with your Raspberry Pi
  • Raspbian QEMU with network ‚Äì Simple tool to launch QEMU on Raspbian with the required modifications on the system and kernel. Automatic network access. Handy to create images in your PC.
  • Resin Bridge ‚Äì Simple application/repo to bridge a Raspberry Pi‚Äôs wlan0 interface to devices plugged into it over ethernet (eth0).
  • stressberry ‚Äì Stress test your Raspberry Pi and plot temperatures.
  • TorTiPi ‚Äì Shell script to automate the task of converting Raspberry Pi into a tor based wifi hotspot.
  • WebStation SYSMON ‚Äì An intuitive remotely-accessible system performance monitoring and task management tool for servers and headless Raspberry Pi setups.
  • WiFi config generator ‚Äì Simple tool to generate wpa_supplicant.conf files with wifi settings

Projects

  • 40-node Raspberry Pi Cluster ‚Äì Cluster aimed to be under the size of full tower desktop.
  • AdGuard Home ‚Äì DNS relay station with ad/tracker/other blocking, IP address redirections, and DNS-over-HTTPS.
  • BeeMonitor ‚Äì Honey beehive monitoring project.
  • Bitcoin Tracker ‚Äì A Physical Dashboard that displays Bitcoin stats in real time.
  • Building a Ceph Cluster on Raspberry Pi ‚Äì Highly redundant and low power usage RADOS home storage solution.
  • Building Timelapse with Resin ‚Äì Remotely deploying timelapse camera using Docker, Resin, and 3G internet.
  • Chromebook Charger Kiosk ‚Äì Timed charging station for students using Chromebooks at school.
  • Ceil ‚Äì Auto-provisioned RPi cluster running K8S on bare-metal.
  • Circle ‚Äì A C++ bare metal environment for Raspberry Pi.
  • clockOS ‚Äì simple smart desktop clock using a Raspberry Pi display.
  • Coder for Raspberry Pi ‚Äì A open source project by Googlers to turn a Raspberry Pi into a simple, tiny, personal web server and web-based development environment.
  • DIY USB Rubber Ducky ‚Äì Raspberry Pi Zero Rubber Ducky recognized as a USB HID by just about anything with a USB port, thus allowing you to run custom scripts as if it were a keyboard.
  • docsis-cable-load-monitor ‚Äì Tool to monitor downstream load on DOCSIS cable networks.
  • Drumbooth controller with touch interface ‚Äì Project using Java, JavaFX, Pi4J and Arduino to control 8 relays and LED strips.
  • FistBump BLE Edition ‚Äì WPA Hash Grabbing Bluetooth Peripheral / Android App.
  • FruitNanny ‚Äì Baby monitor including custom case, server, and client source code.
  • Garage Door Opener ‚Äì Garage door opener using the Garage Opener app to control garage door.
  • Gaussmeter ‚Äì Project utilizing a Raspberry Pi Zero W, WS2812B Leds and the Tesla API to collect and display a Tesla‚Äôs status.
  • Harry Potter and the real life Daily Prophet ‚Äì Display mimicking the Daily Prophet from Harry Potter using a 7‚Ä≥ Raspberry Pi display.
  • Haven ‚Äì Host a private blog on your Rasperry Pi intead of using Facebook.
  • Hearing aid prototoype ‚Äì A Raspberry Pi powered prototype of a hearing aid.
  • Internet Chronometer ‚Äì Turn your Raspberry Pi in to an Internet Chronometer.
  • Jasper ‚Äì Flexible open source personal assistant.
  • Kubernetes on ARM ‚Äì Get your ARM device up and running Kubernetes in less than ten minutes.
  • Lightberry ‚Äì Led lighting solution dedicated for raspberry pi and your TV.
  • Lomorage ‚Äì Private photo cloud host on Raspberry Pi, with Android/iOS/Web client.
  • Looper/synth/drum thing ‚Äì Sequencer/Drumpad, like Native Instruments‚Äô Maschine for the Pi.
  • Lumos ‚Äì Smart Lamp for Better Sleep.
  • Magic Mirror ‚Äì The original open source modular smart mirror platform.
  • Mini OONTZ ‚Äì 3D printed mini MIDI controller.
  • Movel ‚Äì Raspberry Pi car computer.
  • Multi-Datacenter Cassandra on 32 Raspberry Pi‚Äôs ‚Äì Showcase for the always on, fault tolerant nature of Cassandra using a Raspberry Pi cluster board.
  • NALIVATOR-9000 ‚Äì Robot bartender for making cocktails with Telegram-bot interface and speech synthesis on Golang.
  • Nerves Project ‚Äì Craft and deploy bulletproof embedded software in Elixir.
  • Network Presence Detector ‚Äì Setup a Pi Zero to scan for devices on a WiFi network and use that to determine who is ‚Äúhome‚Äù.
  • NTP driven Nixie Clock ‚Äì Nixie Tube Clock powered by a Raspberry Pi.
  • Occu-Pi ‚Äì Controller software for the Occu-pi, a totally awesome bathroom door sensor.
  • P4wnP1 ‚Äì P4wnP1 is a highly customizable USB attack platform, based on a low cost Raspberry Pi Zero or Raspberry Pi Zero W (required for HID backdoor).
  • Pi Image Capturer ‚Äì Captures images, integrated with the Google IOT Cloud Platform ecosystem.
  • pi_payments ‚Äì Payment module based on RFID.
  • Pi-hole ‚Äì Black hole for internet ads.
  • Pi-KVM ‚Äì DIY KVM over IP to manage remote computers via Web UI or VNC with FullHD video, mouse, virtual drive, IPMI, Wake-on-LAN and many other things.
  • pi-timolo ‚Äì Remote Headless multi feature PiCamera Operation from Rclone Remote Storage Service and More.
  • Pi4j Project ‚Äì Java I/O library the Raspberry Pi.
  • PiAware ‚Äì Live flight tracking using a Raspberry Pi.
  • PiClock ‚Äì Fancy Clock built around a monitor and a Raspberry Pi.
  • PiE-Ink ‚Äì E-ink nametag display running on a Pi Zero.
  • PiFanTuner ‚Äì CPU-fan-tuner daemon, just enables your fan as necessary.
  • PiFmRds ‚Äì FM-RDS transmitter using a Raspberry Pi.
  • PiScan ‚Äì Makeshift Amazon Dash orders using a Raspberry PI + EAN scanner.
  • Planning lunch with a Slackbot on resin.io ‚Äì Node.js Slackbot (lunchbot), hosted on Resin.
  • PoisonTap ‚Äì Exploits locked/password protected computers over USB, drops persistent WebSocket-based backdoor, exposes internal router, and siphons cookies using Raspberry Pi Zero & Node.js.
  • Power Sniffing Strip ‚Äì Enclosure in a power strip, sniffing network data.
  • Project MyHouse ‚Äì Smart Doll House with Gesture Recognition, using Raspberry Pi 3 or Pi Zero and PSMove motion controller.
  • Raspberry Pi Dashboard ‚Äì Full-featured web-based dashboard interface to inspect and manage Raspberry Pi hardware and software, with no extra software required.
  • Raspberry Pi Erlang Cluster ‚Äì Erlang cluster on a Raspberry Pi 2.
  • Raspberry PI Hadoop Cluster ‚Äì Big Data cluster running on the Raspberry Pi.
  • RaspiBlitz ‚Äì Fastest and cheapest way to get your own Lightning Node running.
  • RaspiBolt ‚Äì Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Ô∏è‚ö°LightningÔ∏è‚ö° on a Raspberry Pi.
  • Relayboard Control ‚Äì A Qt application to connect a Waveshare 8-channel relay board to an MQTT server.
  • Rhasspy ‚Äì Open source, fully offline set of voice assistant services that works well with Home Assistant, Node-RED, MQTT and more.
  • RPi Motor Library ‚Äì Python 3 library to connect various motors & servos to the Pi.
  • RPI tempmon ‚Äì CPU GPU temperature monitor with various functions such as LED GPIO, Graph output, email, alarm limit, notifications and logging.
  • SecPi ‚Äì Raspberry Pi based home alarm system.
  • Skate-o-Meter ‚Äì Skateboard odometer and speedometer with RFID user system.
  • SkyJack ‚Äì Take over and allow full control over any Parrot AR Drone within wireless distance.
  • Smart Mirror ‚Äì Voice controlled smart mirror with IoT integration.
  • Smart Security Camera ‚Äì Using OpenCV, Twilio and a WebCam/picam.
  • Sonic Pi ‚Äì The Live Coding Music Synth for Everyone.
  • Sonus ‚Äì Node.js voice control for your Pi (and everything else) with customizable offline hotword detection.
  • speed-camera ‚Äì Object Motion Tracking uses python, openCV, USB Cam or picamera module to record speed data.
  • Stratux ‚Äì Open source ADS-B receiver which feeds weather, traffic, GPS, and AHRS data to electronic flight bag software via wifi.
  • StreamPi ‚Äì A robust alternative to the Elgato Stream Deck, that can launch apps, scripts, websites and control applications like OBS.
  • TeslaCam ‚Äì Project utilizing a Raspberry Pi Zero W for USB Mass storage emulation and a PiJuice to collect and archive TeslaCam video.
  • Vinyl Shelf Finder ‚Äì Uses a tilt & pan laser to find a record in a record collection.
  • Voice Kit ‚Äì AIY Voice Kit from Google, to build a standalone voice recognition system using the Google Assistant, or add voice recognition and natural language processing to your Raspberry Pi-based projects.
  • Waves ‚Äì Transforming the transience of the spoken word into something concrete and physical through a microphone, waveform and thermal printer.
  • Whispering Mirror ‚Äì Interactive soundart installation using the Hifiberry DAC.
  • WordPress using Docker ‚Äì Run a WordPress site in containers with dynamic DNS.
  • Zelda Home Automation ‚Äì Home automation based on sound recognition from notes played on an ocarina.

Resources

Useful Apps

  • AndFTP ‚Äì Alternative FTP client app. Android
  • Home Remote Control ‚Äì Control mouse/keyboard, volume, manage download/upload files, custom commands, terminal, execute tasks in future, control media. Android
  • Kore Remote ‚Äì Official remote to control Kodi. Android
  • RasPi Check ‚Äì To check Pi stats ‚Äì frequency, temperature, volts and more system information (free memory, runtime, disk status). You can also restart or halt your Raspberry Pi and send custom commands. Android
  • RaspController ‚Äì Manage your Raspberry Pi remotely, control the GPIO ports, send commands directly through the terminal, view images from a connected camera and obtain data from different sensors. Android
  • Raspicast ‚Äì Cast YouTube videos, media content from your android device, Play local media files, Play streams from playlists (m3u, pls) on your Raspberry Pi. Android
  • Screen Stream Mirroring ‚Äì To stream your phone screen directly to Pi. Android
  • TeamViewer ‚Äì Remote into Raspberry Pi while you are on the road!. Android
  • Termius ‚Äì One of the cleanest SSH Client for Pi. Android, iOS
  • Tubio ‚Äì Cast web videos directly to Pi. Android
  • Turbo FTP ‚Äì A good FTP client app for accessing files on raspberry. Android
  • VNC Viewer ‚Äì To remotely control Raspberry Pi desktop. Android

Articles

  • 10 Ways To Power ‚Äì Information about different & correct ways to power the pi.
  • Raspberry Pi A to Z List ‚Äì Comprehensive list with links to common questions & pitfalls.
  • Raspberry Pi and why do I need one? ‚Äì Intro into the Raspberry Pi and what can be done with it.
  • Raspberry Pi Beginners ‚Äì Guide to setup the Raspberry Pi for beginners.
  • The Ultimate Raspberry Pi Security Guide ‚Äì Extensive guide on security best practices for the Pi ie. exposed to the internet.

Books

  • Control Your Home with Raspberry Pi ‚Äì Teaches you how to turn a Raspberry Pi into a secure, modular, open source and self-hosted home automation gateway with Docker Compose, MQTT and TLS.
  • Essentials ‚Äì AIY Voice Projects ‚Äì Using Google‚Äôs AIY Project Kit, learn how to use artificial intelligence with your Raspberry Pi.
  • Essentials ‚Äì Camera Module Guide ‚Äì How to use your Raspberry Pi Foundation‚Äôs Camera Module with your Raspberry Pi.
  • Essentials ‚Äì Code Music with Sonic Pi ‚Äì Learn how to create music by coding with Sonic Pi on your Raspberry Pi.
  • Essentials ‚Äì Conquer the Command Line (Version 2) ‚Äì Learn how to command and conquer the command line on the Raspberry Pi using Raspbian, simplify complex tasks while you automate simple ones.

content.text:
The Raspberry Pi is a series of credit card-sized single-board computers developed in the United Kingdom by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to promote the teaching of basic computer science in schools and developing countries. Official Link: Raspberry Pi Foundation Homepage, Raspberry Pi Computer Homepage


This list is a collection of tools, projects, images and resources conforming to the Awesome Manifesto
Contributions very welcome but first see Contributing
Contents
Models
OS Images
Tools
Projects
Resources
Models
The complete collection of (consumer) Raspberry Pi models consist of:
Raspberry Pi 1, Model A & Model B (2012, discontinued)

Raspberry Pi 1, Model B+ (July, 2014)

Raspberry Pi 1, Model A+ (November, 2014)

Raspberry Pi 2, Model B (February, 2015)

Raspberry Pi Zero (November, 2015)

Raspberry Pi 3, Model B (March, 2016)

Raspberry Pi Zero W (February, 2017)

Raspberry Pi 3, Model B+ (March, 2018)

Raspberry Pi 3, Model A+ (November, 2018)

Raspberry Pi 4, Model B (June, 2019)

Raspberry Pi 400 (November, 2020)

Raspberry Pi Pico (January, 2021)

Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W (October, 2021)

The Official Raspberry Pi Handbook 2021 ‚Äì A guide to help you get the most of your Raspberry Pi computer, essential information, project ideas, tutorials, and reviews.

The Official Raspberry Pi Handbook 2022 ‚Äì A guide to help you get the most of your Raspberry Pi computer, essential information, project ideas, tutorials, and reviews. Updated for Raspberry Pi Pico.

Tutorials

Auto Mount USB ‚Äì Guide to setup Auto Mount USB on Raspberry Pi.

Bridging Wifi to the Raspberry Pi over Ethernet ‚Äì Set up tethered networking between macOS & Raspberry Pi.

Build a $35 Time Capsule ‚Äì Time Machine Backup Server.

Controlling Spotify with Slack and a Raspberry Pi ‚Äì Node.js project to control Spotify & Slack with libspotify.

DC++ Hub ‚Äì Guide to setup an ADC (DC++) Hub on Raspberry Pi.

DIY Neural Network ‚Äì Uses image recognition and Google‚Äôs Inception to recognize specific objects.

Docker Swarm with LetsEncrypt ‚Äì Clear guidelines on how to set up a cluster with Docker, distributing services with Docker Compose and signing valid SSL certs with Letsencrypt.

How To Make a Raspberry Pi Turn on a Lamp with iBeacon‚Ñ¢ Technology ‚Äì Good beginners-guide to working with Beacon technology.

How to setup a secure VPN server on Raspberry Pi or DigitalOcean ‚Äì Simple, secure and detailed guide to setup VPN on your Raspberry Pi.
Moonlight ‚Äì Nvidia GameStream implementation to stream your full collection of Steam games from desktop to the Raspberry Pi.
Raspbereum ‚Äì Run your own Ethereum node on a Raspberry Pi.

Raspberry Pi Game Console ‚Äì How to Build a Raspberry Pi Retro Game Console for $35.

Raspberry Pi login with SSH keys ‚Äì Password-less login for ssh sessions on the Raspberry Pi.

Raspberry Pi Media Server Guides ‚Äì Media Server and NAS tutorials from HTPC Guides.

Raspberry Pi Zero: Programming over USB ‚Äì Guide to boot and access a Raspberry Pi Zero over a USB cable without need of an ethernet/wifi connection, keyboard or screen. 

Turn a Raspberry Pi into a Plex Media Server ‚Äì Beginners guide to setting up a Plex media server to stream all of your media content.

Turn the Raspberry Pi Zero into a mini dongle computer ‚Äì Setup a pi0 to be able to ssh & vnc over USB. 

Use a Raspberry Pi with multiple WiFi networks ‚Äì Tutorial on using a Raspberry Pi with multiple networks.

Use a Raspberry Pi with Netflix ‚Äì Tutorial on watching Netflix on a Raspberry Pi.

Using openSUSE‚Äôs YaST on the Raspberry Pi.
Swift programming
BuildSwiftOnARM ‚Äì All you need to build Swift on a RaspberryPi or other ARM boards, updated to Swift 4.1.3.

Compile Swift for Raspberry Pi by Xcode ‚Äì Quick tutorial to share the way to help setup compiling Raspberry Pi code with Xcode.

Setup Swift environment on Raspbian ‚Äì Quick guide to help setup Swift environment on Raspbian stretch (lite).
SwiftyGPIO ‚Äì Swift library for hardware projects on Linux/ARM boards with support for GPIOs/SPI/I2C/PWM/UART/1Wire.
Swish ‚Äì Build Swift Projects on a remote machine within Xcode.

content.html:
The difficulty with learning about domains and apache configuration is that ideally, it has to be done in the real world. It‚Äôs not possible to properly emulate the world wide web on a n internal machine ‚Äì but we can make a hybrid!

In times past, we‚Äôve had great ideas which we‚Äôve acted on quickly to secure the right domain ‚Äì it‚Äôs often the first port of call for many a branding ideation session. Of course, not all of those ideas come to fruition and this can leave many domains, sitting, parked and wasting their potential, somewhat.

Hosting is a necessary expense for a website accessible to the web but need not be an expense when it comes to training. An internal VM can be used instead. As long as the VM has a known IP and you don‚Äôt need to see your site outside of its network, you‚Äôll be able to use it.

Setting up the VM

My colleague Mike setup the VMs here at LiquidLight. If you want to follow along with how he did it, he made an excellent write up of it here. After this setup we had a bare VM with the minimal software. Provisioning the server went quite a lot like Mike‚Äôs next article, so I‚Äôll link to that for a concise write up of most of the same requirements of a local server.

How does DNS work?

DNS (Domain Name Service) can be thought of like a phone book of all the world‚Äôs websites. Rather than remembering the IP address of each and every site you want to visit, you remember the name and the name is stored in a database on the DNS with its corresponding IP address.

To look up the IP address from the name, your browser checks on 4 caches to find the relevant IP:

  • The browser cache itself ‚Äì all the sites you‚Äôve visited previously are stored within the cache for a defined period.
  • If unsuccessful, the browser checks the OS cache/hosts file ‚Äì the OS has its own cached list of domains.
  • If not successful with the above, the browser would communicate with the router that maintains its‚Äô own cache of DNS records.
  • Finally, If all these local lookups fail, the browser would move on to the ISP. ISPs retain their own cache of DNS but if they don‚Äôt have the relevant domain, they call on a domain server further and further up the line until they find the correct domain, (at which point, all other devices in the chain update their cache with the correct IP for that domain).

About IP addresses

Your home network may be configured for an IP address like 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1.
10.0.0.1 is more commonly seen in business computer networks than in home networks ‚Äì Like 192.168.0.1, it‚Äôs an internal IP and can only be reached from inside your network.

If you were creating a site you wanted to be reachable on the web, you would point a domain at the hosting server‚Äôs IP, the IP lookup would go through the above process of checking caches and return the external, public IP of the web host.

In this exercise, there was no need for the site to be seen outside of the ‚Äòhome network‚Äô and so, no need to rent any hosting server space from a host.

A VM was created and assigned an IP of 10.0.0.233 and a spare domain had an ‚ÄòA‚Äô name added and pointed to 10.0.0.233. The ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù message on this site won‚Äôt be viewable by anyone outside this internal network and the IP may not even exist to the computer this article is being read on but its reachable from this office and hence can be used to practice setting up domains on this local network, without incurring charges from a web host.

What were the pain points?

The first issue I came across was not being able to ssh into the server on the username I‚Äôd created for it ‚Äì I had dome something wrong in setting it up and now had to trouble shoot ssh connection before I could diagnose any issue at all.
The VM I was trying to reach was called ‚Äòjeremyvm‚Äô and it was installed on our internal server called ‚ÄòPhantom‚Äô. I could reach the VM from Phantom with the following command: sudo xl console jeremyvm

Once inside the VM, I could use sudo su - to become root and start troubleshooting what was and wasn‚Äôt working.

Was it listening on port 22? ~ Yes but I still couldn‚Äôt connect to the VM via SSH.
Was I being blocked by a firewall? ~ Yes! Here‚Äôs the commands that singled me out:

## SSH ##
for i in 82.68.37.54; do
¬† iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 --src $i -j ACCEPT
done
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j DROP

The above is part of the iptables settings to block SSH requests from computers outside of our IP address (the office). The line for i in 82.68.37.54; do means that for the stated IP address, do the following. You can see, on the next line, the word ACCEPT, so if I‚Äôm coming from the right IP address, I should be accepted onto the server as an SSH connection. The problem was, the machines inside the network see the local IP addresses instead of the external IP addresses, hence it looked to the internal iptables like I was trying to connect to the network from an IP that wasn‚Äôt 82.68.37.54 but 10.0.0.10.

  • Browser refused connection
    Solution: It turned out Apache wasn‚Äôt running. Although I‚Äôd set apache to run on the afternoon I did the initial server setup, I hadn‚Äôt put a provision on the machine to make sure Apache was started at bootup. So, the next day, when I came back to configure the rest of the setup, Apache wasn‚Äôt running. This question, answered on StackOverflow gives more detail as to how to set Apache to run at bootup. Although there are differences based on distribution, essentially, every solution involves making a symbolic link from¬†/etc/init.d/¬†to the appropriate run-level folder in¬†/etc/

content.html:
The Raspberry Pi is a series of credit card-sized single-board computers developed in the United Kingdom by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to promote the teaching of basic computer science in schools and developing countries. Official Link:¬†Raspberry Pi Homepage

This list is a collection of tools, projects, images and resources conforming to the¬†Awesome Manifesto

Contributions¬†very welcome¬†but first see¬†Contributing

Contents

  • Models
  • OS Images
  • Tools
  • Projects
  • Resources

Models

The complete collection of (consumer) Raspberry Pi models consist of:

  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model A & Model B (2012, discontinued)
  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model B+¬†(July, 2014)
  • Raspberry Pi 1, Model A+¬†(November, 2014)
  • Raspberry Pi 2, Model B¬†(February, 2015)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero¬†(November, 2015)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model B¬†(March, 2016)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W¬†(February, 2017)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model B+¬†(March, 2018)
  • Raspberry Pi 3, Model A+¬†(November, 2018)

OS Images

  • Alpine Linux¬†‚Äì Security-oriented, lightweight Linux distribution based on musl libc and busybox.
  • Android Things¬†‚Äì Build connected devices for a wide variety of consumer, retail, and industrial applications.¬†
  • Arch Linux ARM¬†‚Äì Lightweight and flexible Linux distribution that tries to Keep It Simple.
  • balenaOS¬†‚Äì open source OS to run Docker containers on embedded devices that‚Äôs been designed for reliability and proven in production.
  • BerryBoot¬†‚Äì Bootloader/universal OS installer, with support to VNC and HDMI-CEC.
  • CentOS¬†‚Äì CentOS on the Raspberry Pi.¬†
  • chilipie-kiosk¬†‚Äì Image which boots directly into full-screen Chrome, perfect for dashboards and build monitors.¬†
  • DietPi¬†‚Äì Minimal image designed to fit on a 2GB SD card, with tons of configurable settings and scripts.
  • DroneBridge¬†‚Äì A WifiBroadcast extension to make for a real alternative to DJI Lightbridge and other similar systems.¬†
  • EZ-WifiBroadcast¬†‚Äì Affordable Wireless Digital HD Video Transmission made easy.¬†¬†
  • FabScanPi¬†‚Äì FabScanPi is an open source 3D laser scanner using the Raspberry Pi Camera Module.¬†
  • Fedora¬†‚Äì Linux Fedora distribution built for the Pi.¬†
  • FreeBSD¬†‚Äì FreeBSD is an advanced computer operating system used to power modern servers, desktops, and embedded platforms.
  • Gentoo¬†‚Äì Gentoo Stage 3 tarball for Raspberry Pi.
  • Gladys Project¬†‚Äì Gladys, Your home assistant.¬†
  • Hass.io¬†‚Äì Home automation operating system/application for embedded device, also available standalone.
  • HypriotOS¬†‚Äì Minimal Debian-based operating system, optimized to run Docker.
  • Kali Linux¬†‚Äì Penetration Testing & Ethical Hacking Linux distro for ARM devices.
  • Kano OS¬†‚Äì Open-source OS for exploration, creation, and play ‚Äì free for Raspberry Pi and the new Pi 3.
  • Lakka¬†‚Äì Retro-gaming on the Raspberry Pi built entirely on RetroArch.
  • Minibian¬†‚Äì Minimal Raspbian (lighter than Jessie Lite).
  • MoodleBox¬†‚Äì The MoodleBox provides a Moodle learning management system on Raspberry Pi.¬†
